title: What’s that ringing in your ears? - Marc Fagelson

multiple-choice.question: What is tinnitus?

options.label: A
options.text: A disease that affects the eyes.

options.label: C
options.text: The perception of a noise like ringing, buzzing, hissing, or clicking without any external source of sound.

options.label: D
options.text: A mental disorder that causes hallucinations.

multiple-choice.question: How common is tinnitus?

options.label: A
options.text: It affects only a small percentage of the population.

options.label: B
options.text: It affects roughly one in seven people worldwide.

options.label: C
options.text: It affects only people who have been exposed to loud noises.

options.label: D
options.text: It affects only people who have a family history of the condition.

multiple-choice.question: Where do the nerve signals that produce tinnitus come from?
What can damage cochlear cells and lead to tinnitus?

options.label: D
options.text: Loud noises, diseases, toxins, and natural aging.

multiple-choice.question: What is subjective tinnitus?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of tinnitus that is caused by a physical disorder.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of tinnitus that is caused by a mental disorder.

options.label: C
options.text: A symptom associated with practically every known ear disorder.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of tinnitus that is caused by a virus.

multiple-choice.question: What is bothersome tinnitus?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of tinnitus that is not bothersome.

options.label: B
options.text: A condition that can exacerbate the symptoms of PTSD, insomnia, anxiety, and depression.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of tinnitus that is caused by a physical disorder.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of tinnitus that is caused by a mental disorder.

multiple-choice.question: Is there a known cure for subjective tinnitus?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, there is a known cure.

options.label: B
options.text: No, there is no known cure.

options.label: C
options.text: The cure is still being researched.

options.label: D
options.text: The cure is only available for some people.

multiple-choice.question: What is sound therapy?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of surgery that can cure tinnitus.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of medication that can cure tinnitus.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of therapy that uses noises to mask tinnitus and reduce stress.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of therapy that uses music to cure tinnitus.

multiple-choice.question: What is informational masking?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of sound therapy that uses soothing, complex auditory signals to distract the brain from the tinnitus sound.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of sound therapy that uses sounds with the same frequency as the patient's tinnitus to occupy the neurons that would otherwise deliver the tinnitus signal.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of sound therapy that uses music to cure tinnitus.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of sound therapy that uses white noise to cure tinnitus.

multiple-choice.question: What is energetic masking?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of sound therapy that uses soothing, complex auditory signals to distract the brain from the tinnitus sound.

options.label: B
options.text: A type of sound therapy that uses sounds with the same frequency as the patient's tinnitus to occupy the neurons that would otherwise deliver the tinnitus signal.

options.label: C
options.text: A type of sound therapy that uses music to cure tinnitus.

options.label: D
options.text: A type of sound therapy that uses white noise to cure tinnitus.

title: Can you outsmart the fallacy that fooled a generation of doctors? - Elizabeth Cox

multiple-choice.question: What was the major debate among physicians in 1843?
According to Charles Meigs, what was the cause of childbed fever?
What is the false cause fallacy?

options.label: A
options.text: When two phenomena regularly occur together, one necessarily causes the other

options.label: B
options.text: When two phenomena regularly occur together, one does not necessarily cause the other

options.label: C
options.text: When two phenomena do not occur together, one necessarily causes the other

options.label: D
options.text: When two phenomena do not occur together, one does not necessarily cause the other

multiple-choice.question: What was Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes' theory on the cause of childbed fever?

options.label: B
options.text: Poor hygiene and invisible contaminants on doctors' hands and surgical instruments

multiple-choice.question: Why did most doctors reject Dr. Holmes' theory?

options.label: A
options.text: They thought it was too simple

options.label: B
options.text: They thought it was too complex

options.label: C
options.text: They saw themselves as infallible and refused to consider the possibility of infecting patients

options.label: D
options.text: They thought it was too expensive to implement

multiple-choice.question: What initiative did Ignaz Semmelweis implement to reduce childbed fever deaths?

options.label: A
options.text: Requiring all medical personnel to disinfect their hands after autopsies and between patient examinations

options.label: B
options.text: Requiring all medical personnel to wear gloves during patient examinations

options.label: C
options.text: Requiring all medical personnel to use antibiotics during patient treatment

options.label: D
options.text: Requiring all medical personnel to isolate patients with childbed fever

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of Ignaz Semmelweis' initiative?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of childbed fever deaths increased

options.label: B
options.text: The number of childbed fever deaths remained the same

options.label: C
options.text: The number of childbed fever deaths decreased from 12% to 1%

options.label: D
options.text: The number of childbed fever deaths decreased from 1% to 0%

multiple-choice.question: Who identified the contaminant responsible for many cases of childbed fever in 1879?
What was the contaminant responsible for many cases of childbed fever identified by Louis Pasteur?
What is the main lesson from the story about childbed fever?

options.label: C
options.text: Correlation does not necessarily imply causation, and careful investigation is needed to determine the cause of a phenomenon

options.label: D
options.text: Doctors are infallible and never make mistakes

title: The greatest mathematician that never lived - Pratik Aghor

options.label: C
options.text: He did not exist as a real person.

options.label: D
options.text: He was not a French mathematician.

options.label: A
options.text: To create a new branch of mathematics.

options.label: B
options.text: To unify every branch of mathematics under a consistent logical framework.

options.label: C
options.text: To prove a specific mathematical theorem.

options.label: D
options.text: To develop a new mathematical methodology.

multiple-choice.question: How did the group of mathematicians define a function in their work?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: As a bridge between two groups that establishes logical relationships between them.

options.label: C
options.text: As a set of simple axioms.

multiple-choice.question: What is an injective function, according to the group's definition?

options.label: A
options.text: A function where every output can be mapped onto at least one input.

options.label: B
options.text: A function where every numerical input corresponds to the same alphabetical output.

options.label: C
options.text: A function where every numerical input corresponds to a different alphabetical output.

options.label: D
options.text: A function where the output comes from a unique input.

multiple-choice.question: What is a bijective function, according to the group's definition?

options.label: A
options.text: A function where every output can be mapped onto at least one input.

options.label: B
options.text: A function where every numerical input corresponds to the same alphabetical output.

options.label: C
options.text: A function where every numerical input corresponds to a different alphabetical output.

options.label: D
options.text: A function where each element has perfect one-to-one correspondence.

options.text: To avoid criticism from other mathematicians.

options.label: B
options.text: To mark the occasion of their revolutionary work.

options.label: C
options.text: To prove that mathematics is an intuitive science.

options.text: To show that logic constrains creativity.

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Whether there are universal grammar rules and whether these rules are specific to each language.

options.label: D
options.text: Whether there are universal grammar rules and whether these rules are necessary for language acquisition.

multiple-choice.question: What is the analytical tool developed by Chomsky to establish the universal rules of grammar?
What is the term for the principle that structures can be nested inside each other, proposed by Chomsky as a universal grammar rule?
Which Amazonian language was found to not have recursive structures, challenging Chomsky's theory?
What was the dominant paradigm that Chomsky's theory of universal grammar challenged?
According to scientists today, what is the current understanding of language acquisition?

options.label: A
options.text: Language is acquired solely through experience and learning.

options.label: B
options.text: Language is acquired through a combination of experience and innate biological machinery.

options.label: C
options.text: Language is acquired solely through innate biological machinery.

options.label: D
options.text: Language is acquired through a process that is not yet fully understood.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of Chomsky's theory of universal grammar on the field of linguistics?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a decrease in the study of languages.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to an increase in the study of languages, but only in the Western world.

options.label: C
options.text: It led to an increase in the study of languages, including many that had not been studied before.

options.label: D
options.text: It had no significant impact on the field of linguistics.

multiple-choice.question: What is the current understanding of the biology responsible for language learning?

options.label: A
options.text: It is specific to language and isolated from other aspects of cognition.

options.label: B
options.text: It is shared with other aspects of cognition, but the exact relationship is not yet fully understood.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not yet fully understood and requires further research.

options.label: D
options.text: It is solely based on behaviorist principles.

title: When is a pandemic over?

multiple-choice.question: What is the main factor that determines when the World Health Organization (WHO) will declare a pandemic over?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of deaths from the virus

options.label: B
options.text: The rate of transmission of the virus

multiple-choice.question: What are the three main options that governments have to respond to a pandemic?

options.label: B
options.text: Race through it, Delay and Vaccinate, or Coordinate and Crush

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of the "Delay and Vaccinate" strategy?

options.label: A
options.text: To allow people to be exposed to the virus as quickly as possible

options.label: B
options.text: To slow the spread of the virus to give research facilities time to produce a vaccine

options.label: C
options.text: To starve the virus through a combination of quarantine, social distancing, and restricting travel

multiple-choice.question: What is the critical factor in the "Coordinate and Crush" strategy?

options.label: C
options.text: The rate of transmission of the virus

multiple-choice.question: Which strategy is generally considered to be the best option for responding to a pandemic?

options.label: D
options.text: Vaccination, assisted by as much global coordination as possible

multiple-choice.question: What is the main benefit of the "Vaccination, assisted by as much global coordination as possible" strategy?

options.label: C
options.text: It can eradicate the virus completely

options.label: D
options.text: It can protect people from the virus even after the pandemic officially ends

multiple-choice.question: What is the potential risk of the "Coordinate and Crush" strategy?

options.label: B
options.text: The virus may not be completely eradicated

options.label: C
options.text: The strategy may not work at all if people can be reinfected

multiple-choice.question: What is the main legacy of a pandemic?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of deaths from the virus

options.label: B
options.text: The economic impact of the pandemic

options.label: C
options.text: The breakthroughs, social services, and systems developed during the pandemic

multiple-choice.question: What can be used to make viruses much less dangerous?

options.label: C
options.text: Breakthroughs in treatment and prevention of symptoms

multiple-choice.question: What is the ultimate goal of responding to a pandemic?

options.label: B
options.text: To protect people from the virus

options.label: C
options.text: To minimize the impact of the pandemic

options.label: D
options.text: To keep the next potential pandemic so contained that our children's children won't even know its name
